Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Rechargeable Networks with Energy Cooperation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless energy transfer for energy harvesting communications will introduce a new breed of wireless networks with extended lifetime, deployable in challenging conditions or locations including in-infrastructure and in-body applications. Such nodes will not only harvest energy from nature to continually recharge their batteries but will be able to share energy with similar devices in the network via wireless energy transfer for uninterrupted and perpetual operation. Energy cooperation through wireless energy transfer adds a significant new dimension on top of energy harvesting from natural resources, by giving nodes the ability to transfer some of their energies to neighboring nodes as needed. This technology enables the energy-receiving nodes to harvest energy from a man-made source via a targeted and optimized energy transfer process. As such, this technology is useful as an additional source of energy, as a mechanism to regulate the pace of incoming energy when ambient resources fluctuate and could be the only dependable energy source when ambient resources are not sufficient.

This project investigates communication theory, optimization and networking aspects of energy harvesting wireless networks with wireless energy transfer in order to determine the optimum transmission, scheduling, reception and networking methods for such systems. The researchers aim to determine the optimum wireless energy transfer times and amounts, on top of the energy harvesting profile of the user from natural energy sources, so as to optimize the overall energy arrival profile at the energy receiving node, to maximize the given objective of the user. In addition, the researchers aim to investigate energy cooperation schemes at the battery level that together with signal cooperation schemes at the physical layer improve the end-to-end throughput of the system in small to medium size networks. Finally, the researchers will study joint energy and information routing in multi-hop cooperative wireless networks, where energy and information flow together in the system due to wireless energy transfer. The researchers aim to develop practical, distributed, local measurement-based, back-pressure type algorithms for the control of both data and energy queues in the network.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has investigated the novel concept of energy cooperation with the goal of designing energy sustainable wireless networks of the future. The paradigm of wireless energy transfer for energy harvesting communications, introduces the possibility of a new breed of wireless networks with extended lifetime, deployable in challenging conditions or locations including in-infrastructure and in-body applications. Such nodes not only harvest energy from nature to continually recharge their batteries, but also are able to share energy with similar devices in the network via wireless energy transfer for uninterrupted and perpetual operation. Energy cooperation through wireless energy transfer adds a significant new dimension on top of energy harvesting from natural resources, by giving nodes the ability to transfer some of their energies to neighboring nodes as needed. This technology enables the energy-receiving nodes to harvest energy from a man-made source via a targeted and optimized energy transfer process. As such, this technology is useful as an additional source of energy, as a mechanism to regulate the pace of incoming energy when ambient resources fluctuate and could be the only dependable energy source when ambient resources are not sufficient.

 

The major technical outcomes of this project include the development of resource allocation and network design strategies for energy cooperating energy harvesting networks. A broad range of network topologies has been considered including small and medium size networks, two hop networks, and cognitive radio networks. Offline and online throughput optimal transmission policies have been identified. Overall, the project has provided a comprehensive study of communication theory, optimization and networking aspects of energy harvesting wireless networks with wireless energy transfer, and identified design insights by determining the optimum transmission, scheduling, reception and networking methods for such systems.

 

Educational outcomes of this research have included incorporation of the produced research results into graduate and undergraduate curriculum, in communication theory, digital communications and wireless communication theory courses. Outreach activities have consisted of invited lectures, keynotes and tutorials at international conferences, workshops and summer schools.

 

Human development and training outcomes of this research include training of PhD students at the University of Maryland and at the collaborative institution Penn State, on optimization, wireless communication theory, networking and wireless energy harvesting networks. The project enabled the participants to conduct research on energy-sustainable wireless communications, and collaborate with their peers and the PIs at the two institutions.
